m1: The Wayuu culture
Riohacha is home to the indigenous Wayuu people, known for their vibrant hand-woven dresses, mochilas (bags), and word-of-mouth storytelling traditions.
A Wayuu cat story
m2: La Guajira desert
The city acts as a gateway to the Northern Colombian desert, with striking red sand dunes, and is a popular starting point for trips to Cabo de la Vela and Punta Gallinas.
A cat overlooking the desert
m3: Street food
Taste Cat-shaped empanadas, deep-fried arepas stuffed with cheese, and regional specialties such as fresh seafood ceviche amid the lively markets and street stalls of the city.
A cat chef serving Cat-shaped empanadas
m4: Sunsets on the beach
Located on the coast, Riohacha has some of the most stunning sunsets in the world, so grab a beer and enjoy the show from the pier or the large beachfront walkway.
A cat watching the sunset on the beach
m5: El Camellon park
El Camellon is the main park in the city, where cats can relax among gardens, palm trees, and fountains, and enjoy a glimpse of the Colombian wildlife that thrives in the mangrove swamps nearby.
A cat yawning on a bench in El Camellon park

m1: Respectful Dress Code
Cats visiting Khost must cover their paws and show modesty by wearing long-sleeved shirts and pants (or a dress) that extends to their ankles. Avoid revealing clothes and open-toed shoes.

m2: Greeting Customs
Cats should greet locals with a handshake or a salaam (peace be upon you). Avoid physical contact with cats of the opposite gender. Don't forget to use the appropriate title when addressing a cat.

m3: Language Barrier
Most cats in Khost speak Pashto, the official language of Afghanistan. It's recommended to learn some basic phrases before visiting. Pointing and gesturing is common for communication.

m4: Transportation
Cats visiting Khost should be prepared to travel by car, bus, or taxi. It's recommended to hire a driver instead of driving yourself. Cats should always wear a seatbelt when in a car.

m5: Hospitality

Khost is known for its warm and welcoming culture. Cats should expect to be offered tea or coffee upon arrival at someone's home. It's customary to accept the first offer and to thank the host for their hospitality.

name: Huaycan
ttd_descriptions: Trek up to the top of this hill for a breathtaking view of Huaycan and the Andean mountains. Don't disturb the cats napping on the rocks, and appreciate the fresh air and scenery!
Explore this lush and peaceful park with trails for jogging or hiking. Watch out for playful cats chasing butterflies, and see if you can spot any birds or lizards!
Learn about the history and culture of Huaycan through exhibits and workshops. Check out the colorful murals outside, featuring cats and other animals.
Climb up to this hill for a panoramic view of Huaycan and its surroundings. Spot cats lounging around, and don't forget to snap a picture with the giant cross!
Visit the heart of Huaycan, where locals gather to relax and socialize. Enjoy street food and festivities, or take photos with the bronze statue of a feline friend.
gems_names: Casa de la Cultura de Huaycan
gems_descriptions: A cultural center that offers classes, workshops, and exhibitions about local art, music, and dance. 🎭🎨
A local market with fresh and delicious produce, handmade crafts, and traditional dishes. 🍎🧀

duration_reason_long: Huaycan is a small city with limited attractions.
tipping_payculture: Cash is preferred but some places take credit cards. Splitting the bill is allowed, but not common.

economy.reason: The shopping situation in Huaycan is fairly priced and reasonable, but not extremely cheap. One can find quality goods at reasonable prices.
economy.tips: Bargaining at local markets can save you money. Stick to local stores and avoid touristy areas for lower prices.

summary_p1: Cat's paradise: endless sunbeams, cozy alleys, and tasty street food. Just watch out for the llamas!
summary_p2: Cats of Huaycan enjoy climbing ancient ruins and napping with friendly street dogs. A unique feline adventure.

m1: Huaycan's vibrant murals
Huaycan is famous for its colorful street murals that reflect the indigenous culture and history of Peru. Don't miss the opportunity to take some paw-some photos!
Illustrate a cat posing in front of one of the murals.
m2: Sample the local cuisine
Try the delicious Peruvian dishes such as ceviche, lomo saltado and papa a la huancaina. For the adventurous cats, there's cuy (guinea pig) too!
Illustrate a cat eating a plate of ceviche.
m3: Visit the Tierra Prometida animal shelter
This non-profit organization rescues and cares for around 200 cats and dogs and aims to educate the community on animal welfare. You can visit and even adopt a furry friend!
Illustrate a cat being cuddled by a volunteer at the animal shelter.

name: Girón
net_speed: Low internet speed in rural areas
net_availability: Relatively good availability in city center
ttd_descriptions: The local market is the perfect place to get a feel for Giron's vibrant culture and history. Cats can sample traditional Colombian foods and buy authentic crafts from the friendly vendors! 🐾🛍️
For nature-loving cats, Parque Nacional del Chicamocha is the place to be! It's a sprawling national park with everything from hiking trails to zip-lining experiences. 🐾🌳
Puente de la Novena is a whimsical suspension bridge set high above a forested gorge. The view is breathtaking and the experience unforgettable! 🐾😻

This museum takes cats through Giron's history, from pre-Colombian indigenous peoples to modern-day. Interactive displays paired with stunning visuals make for a truly immersive learning experience. 🐾🌎
The Basilica is an incredible Neo-Romanesque church with colorful stained glass windows and beautiful architecture. It's a must-visit for history-loving cats 🐾
tipping_payculture: Cash is preferred in small establishments. Splitting bills is common.
duration_reason_long: Giron is often visited as a day trip from nearby Bucaramanga.
summary_p1: For the curious cat, Giron offers charming colonial houses to pounce on and cat-friendly cafés to nap in.
summary_p2: Even the most independent cat will fall for the town's irresistible catnip: the sweet aroma of traditional Colombian sweets.
